Which professors should I avoid
What courses have the heaviest workload
Which courses have the heaviest workload
Is CS stressful if I haven't coded before

messages.content: PAM recommends meeting with the CSE Peer Advisors. Peer Advisors support all engineering students by using their student perspective to advise you on various topics including: major and minor selection, course requirements, undergraduate research, post-graduation planning, experiential learning, among other campus resources. You can sign up with one here. An additional resource you may use is your navigator who can point you in the right direction or help connect you to offices on campus that can help with your questions. You can find the name of your navigator under the advisors tab on SIS or sign up with an undedicated one here.

messages.content: Some classes offer SI (supplemental instruction) sessions; you can see if these are available for your class here. You can also find an individual tutor here and group study sessions here. If your class is not listed as an option, you can reach out to academic services to request that a peer tutor be found for your class (information linked on the same page).

messages.content: Classes for next semester are scheduled by the department at least one semester in advance (and often multiple semesters). Classes are also generally offered in the same pattern they are historically offered which is something students can check on SIS when they click on the 'previously offered' tab for each course in the course search page. PAM recommends working with either your academic advisor (found under advisors on SIS) or the CSE Peer Advisors to get help creating a 4 year class plan or simply plan your courses for next semester in advance!

You can find out more information about co-op by emailing the director Genine gma19@case.edu or through this link. If you are a BA student, you can check out the practicum page.

Which depth track should I choose

messages.content:
BA Computer Science majors don't pick a depth track, but if you're a BS CS major you can pick between

  1. Software Engineering
  2. Algorithms and Theory
  3. Computer Systems, Networks and Security
  4. Databases and Data Mining
  5. Bioinformatics
  6. Artificial Intelligence

should I get a masters
Do I need a masters in CS
Do I need a masters in computer science
Can I get a job without a masters degree
Can I get a job with a BA in CS
Can I get a job with a BS in CS
Should I get a masters or a job
Do I need a masters degree to get a job
Why should I get a masters degree

messages.content:
A master’s degree in Computer Science provides students with experiential and applied learning in the field. Through this graduate program, you’ll gain a higher-level understanding of everything you need to succeed in computing and information science. Read more here

That being said here are some of the pros and cons of getting a Masters. Pros: If you are interested in continuing with your masters degree in computer science, you'll find better pay, good job outlook, and the opportunity to stand out from other job applicants. Cons: Earning a masters degree comes with more student debt and more time spend in school.

CWRU also offers an integrate BS/MS program in which you can earn your bachelors and masters in ony 5 years. You can read more here
Okay, search for programs is cancelled.
